The food was good, but there are birds everywhere that the staff seems to ignore, so just watch your plates. We didn't eat at the hotel, but you need to plan a bit as the resort is remote, or you'll be stuck with the food at the Ritz--good food, but expensive. Rent a car! There are really nice restaurants in Maui, but you need to be able to get to them. The parking area isn't well marked--we ended up valet parking ($15/day) the first night b/c we didn't realize that the sign that says "valet parking only" is at the entrance of valet, employee, and guest parking. The grouds are beautiful, the pool is nice, the gym is top-rate--personal flat-screen tvs for all cardio, full nautilus, steam room, sauna...towels and water plentiful, as also at the pool and the beach. Speaking of the beach, there is a bit of a walk--five minutes tops, and if you don't want to walk, the staff is happy to take you up in a cart. All in all, the stay was very good. Someone mentioned that not every room got a newspaper. Well, newspapers (the Wall Street Journal) were available in the hallways. Maybe they didn't want to waste newspapers by deliverying them to every door, especially since there were a lot of non-English speaking guests there. They were easily available to anyone who wanted one. The resort wasn't perfect, but the staff's willingness to rectify any problems was what impressed me. And the twice-daily housekeeping services.

Reviews.Title: “Nickel and Dimed”
Reviews.Author: jeg3k
Reviews.Content: I just visited the Ritz Carlton. While the service and grounds are what can be expected from a five star hotel, I was extremely disappointed with what amounted to nickel and diming everything on the resort. Although we were warned about the $15/day resort fee, there was pretty much nothing offered for this fee. We didn't even receive a daily newspaper. There were newspapers available in the lobby areas, but nothing was delivered to our room. The Partial Ocean View was misleading, as the view was blocked by trees. The prices for drinks and food was astronomical. I understand that this is a five star resort with world-renowned chefs, but to charge $4.50 for a coke by the pool is a little excessive. If you do choose to stay, eat your meals in Lahaina, where the food is great, the views can be great, and the prices, while not cheap, are reasonable.

Reviews.Title: “internet problems / parking”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: This might be nit picking considering how beautiful the resort is...however.... The internet access at the Ritz is not what I would expect at a five start hotel. The hotel does not offer plug in access in the room. The only option is wireless which you have to pay for. They suggest a third party company for wireless access. The signal was supposed to be available throughout the resort. Unfortunately, the signal was very weak everywhere in the hotel and was worthless. I had to cancel my subscription. The other option is wireless access through the hotel's business center (which you also have to pay for). It worked ok, but you have to be within 20 or 30 feet of the business center which is in a dark, windowless hallway. I would have liked to have been able to check my email in my room, or even in the lobby or out by the pool...alas it was not to be. The Ritz needs to do alot of work to improve its internet access. Also, the hotel staff was pretty clueless about internet access at the hotel. The resort offers free self parking (actually its not free, but its included in the mandatory $15 per night resort fee). The only problem is that a single lot holds valet, guests and employees. You would expect the valet parking to be in the front....no problem. But one would think that the hotel employees would park in the back of the lot, the furthest from the resort....not so fast. The parking lot went from valet (closest) to employees (next closest) and finally to guests. I certainly didn't enjoy getting back to the hotel at 10:00 p.m. after dinner, parking in the guest section, and walking past several rows of employee parking to get back to the resort.

Reviews.Title: “Fantastic Stay at the Ritz”
Reviews.Author: anaheimangels
Reviews.Content: My wife and I recently returned from a great stay in July of 2004 at the Ritz. I read some of the negative reviews about the Ritz before we went to Maui. After having stayed at this fine establishment, it is amazing to me that some people can think of so many things to complain about when it comes to a hotel. We thought the Ritz was a beautiful and classy resort. We also stayed several nights at the Hyatt on Kaanapali Beach. The Hyatt was nice. However, the beach near the Ritz is much nicer than Kaanapali Beach. Yes, it is true that you must walk a couple of minutes to the beach near the Ritz. It is rather pathetic if you feel it is too exhausting to include a brief walk to the beach during your vacation. As a note, there can be more wind at the Ritz than at the hotels on Kaanapali Beach. However, it was 88 degrees and quite humid during our stay and the wind was very refreshing. In any event, wherever you go and wherever you stay, have fun!

Reviews.Title: “First Class All the Way!”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: We thoroughly enjoyed our honeymoon at the Ritz Kapalua. I was a bit skeptical after reading some of the poor reviews on this website before we went. The grounds are amazing and the pool is not like an aquatic playground, but it is tasteful and large enough so you don't feel like you're on top of everyone, which is how it is at most of the other resorts. Our room was always kept spotless, with twice a day cleaning service. The staff was extremely nice and helpful with making or cancelling any reservations. If you are looking for a lot of people and pools with waterslides, then you should look in Kaanapali. If you are looking for a tasteful resort on the most gorgeous property in Maui, then the Ritz is for you. Another popular complaint is that the beach is so far away. Are we Americans that lazy?! The beach is not even a three minute walk from the pool and it's a better beach than Kaanapali by far because it is very spreadout. The beaches in Kaanapali are very small and there isn't much beach. The resort is pushed up on the hill because down by the beach is an ancient Hawaaiin burial ground, so they couldn't build on top of it. The way the resort is pushed back on a cliff allows for it to be spread out and also offers amazing views. The bocci court and nine putting greens are also a nice touch. Oh, and did I mention the staff that comes around with fresh slices of pineapple while you are lounging by the pool? Wonderful! Another complaint we read about was the wind. Kapalua is a windy part of the island, but the breeze felt wonderful with the hot sun. It is nothing that would keep you from lying by the pool or anything. I guess there is always going to be someone who is going to complain about something. And to the people who were complaining about the room size! I know the hotel is a bit expensive, but you're not just paying for the room, you're paying for the resort. And why are you spending so much time in your room in Maui anyway?! Overall, we give the Ritz a five star rating and we can't wait to go back. We give the breakfast buffet an 11 out of 10. It is a MUST!

Reviews.Title: “Such a disappointment!”
Reviews.Author: VegasCanuck
Reviews.Content: We stayed at the Maui Ritz Carlton for 4 days in early July. Although we are frequent visitors to Hawaii, we had never stayed at this property before and we will never stay there again. I am not one of the hyper-critical reviewers that you come across online but I do have high expectations when I stay at a property such as a Ritz Carlton. I'm happy to pay $400+ a night but I hate to get ripped off with poor accommodations and poor service. I've stayed at some very nice Ritz Carlton properties such as the Chicago and Hong Kong locations but this Maui resort is not one of them. We had two rooms and they were both quite worn. The cheap furniture(especially the TV credenza) has not aged well. The TV was something you would find in a 1970's Ramada...very strange! Overall cleanliness should have been better, especially around the toilet paper holders...gross! They use an industrial strength air freshener in the rooms that can be quite overwhelming. At least the bed was comfortable. Where are the flowers? At most Hawaiian resorts, you are surrounded by fresh orchids in bathrooms, hallways, etc. There were very few at this property. The room service that we used several times did not even come with a flower...something that a Marriott in Kansas City can do...why not the Ritz in Maui? There is a very stinky type of plant they have on their grounds near the rooms...why don't they get rid of them? The beach is not your typical Hawaiian resort beach...way down the hill from the hotel. It looked more like a beach you would find in Wisconsin. Dark murky water and mostly pine trees. The hotel pool was small for Hawaii standards and void of any character. The staff was less than helpful. Not once did they ask if we needed directions when we picked our car up from the valet(we encountered this courtesy at every other resort we visited during the trip). Details make the difference and this hotel is lacking in them. There are some superb resorts in Maui but this is not one of them.

Reviews.Title: “some truth to the rumors”
Reviews.Author: MauiMarkCT
Reviews.Content: After 23 trips to maui, all on the wailea side, we decided to try 2 weeks in kapalua. In reading the reviews here, we discounted the rain stories as being negative advertising for four seasons as some messages referred to. The hotel is awesome, the views spectacular, the service was impeccable. BUT we were suppose to stay 17 days in kapalua and we only lasted 10. I played golf every morning, early around 7, and i was rained on every single day. We experienced "showers" everyday but 1 at the pool with 4 of those days having showers that lasted over an hour. The staff commented that May and june are normally not like this, i must say that my trip confirmed the fact that it rains (alot) in kapalua. Also a negative to the trip was we parked our car using valet service, on the 3rd night my rental car was keyed. upon getting my car and immediately noticing, the bell desk was very helpful and concerned. The ensuing security department involvement was just short of making me feel like i was a criminal. The entire conversation revolved exclusively around where this could have happened because it was not something that would occur there. Thank god for LDW. other than that one incident if the hotel was anywhere in wailea i would go again, but the rain definitely put a damper on our first 10 days. We have stayed in wailea on all of our other trips and have only seen rain 1 time in all of those trips. For the record, we have never stayed at the Four Seasons, we have stayed at the Wailea Marriott (former Intercontinental/Aston/Outrigger), the prince in makena, and the grand wailea (where we finished our vacation and where we will return to in november) (see review under that hotel)

Reviews.Title: “Beautiful”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: We just returned from 5 nights at the Ritz. The place is beautiful. The grounds are magnificent, the service great and the atmosphere very relaxing. We did have a slightly mildewey room and we were given a dehumidifier to help. The breakfast buffet is great (included with our package). The concierge desk was extremely helpful giving us directions, resturant choices and touring advice. The beach is a lovely little spot just down the hill from the building. It was relatively uncrowded the days we were there (most people stick to the pool). If the walk back up is too daunting, they run a golf cart shuttle. The only problem arose at checkout time when our stay 4 nights get the 5th free package didn't show up on our bill. Fortunately they resolved the issue to our satisfaction without too much kicking and screaming. The Ritz does know how to take care of its guests.

Reviews.Title: “Paradise in Maui”
Reviews.Author: gr8puck
Reviews.Content: Aloha! We just returned from spending 5 nights and 6 days at the gorgeous Ritz-Carlton Kapalua. The property is amazing. I wonder if the negative reviewers could ever be happy at any property. I suspect they spend their time looking for something to complain about rather than looking at the positive things life has to offer. We found the hotel to offer elevated levels of service; from the constant Aloha greetings from staff members, to the twice-daily housekeeping service. Everything was picture perfect. The hotel is located on a bluff overlooking the Pacific. The lobby is on the eighth floor, which is the entry lobby level, and the rooms are on the lower levels. The beach might as well be the Ritzâ€™s private beach, (there are no private beaches in Hawaii, all must offer and have public access), as there was only a handful of beach goers during our entire stay. Previous reviewers mentioned the terrible lengthy walk to the beach, yet it is only 385 steps, I counted, from the poolâ€™s edge to the sand. The hotel offers golf cart shuttles down to the beach for those unwilling or unable to make the 385 step walk down to the beach. The walk to the beach is on a stone paved, lit, walkway. At the end of the walkway, on the beach, is the Beach House CafÃ©, where we enjoyed a delightful breakfast of an egg white frittata, an egg and local sausage quesadilla, with some tropical smoothies. This is a nice spot to enjoy the Hawaiian sunsets with a delicious tropical beverage and local appetizers. We did learn, as I am certain the negative reviewers did, that the hotel is on the bluff as the lower portion of the property is a sacred Hawaiian burial area about 1000 years old. The area is a protected site, is clearly marked with stone markers and landscaped with native hedges. It is a nice area to reflect on the history of the island and its people. For those interested, the service is top notch, the rooms are tastefully decorated, about 450 square feet, large bathrooms, with a separate glass shower and tub, the toilet is housed in itâ€™s own little room, double sinks, a bath scale, hair dryers, in room safe, ironing board, iron, and soft thick white cotton Ritz-Carlton robes. The hotel offers TV cable with enough channels to keep the TV watcher fully occupied. Twice daily housekeeping service keeps the room nice and tidy. The room lanai offers outdoor chairs, an ottoman, and a table. One has the choice of closing off the outside world with draperies, shutters, or if one desires, opening up the room to the lanai using the screen slider instead of the glass doors. The beds come with feather bed toppers, which made me, feel like being at home in my own bed. The hotel offers a choice of valet parking for a daily fee or â€œfreeâ€� self-parking for quests. For the beach goer, the hotel has big green beach towels, and boogie boards. In the pool area the hotel has towel service, food and beverage service, and live soft hawaiian music playing in an tented area near the outside bar area. For those not wishing to have every meal on the property on has options. The Honoloa Market, just across from the valet area, offers breakfast and lunch from its kitchen. One can eat the local goodies in the marketâ€™s front porch area. The market was the old post office and gathering place for the locals. Try their chocolate chip cookies, pretty yummy. There are also many fine restaurants in the Kapalua area, just minutes from the hotel and all without having to drive on the main highway. The hotel offers morning coffee in the open lobby, which is open to a view of the pool and ocean. This is a nice area to catch up on the news, a book, and a great cup of java. My only disappointment was the constant pointless cell phone conversations guests were having at this time of the morning. I say point less because the majority started the conversation with, â€œWhat are you doing,â€� they were also loud as if they were competing with each other on who was more important. So much for a quite tranquil morning in Paradise. However I do not consider this to be a hotel problem. This is a very tranquil quiet property, even the pool area is low keyed, so if you prefer something noisier and in the thick of things, then head to the Kaanapali area and join the party crowd. Otherwise, come prepared for an enjoyable remarkable time in paradise.

Reviews.Title: “Outstanding”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: Me and my wife just came back from our honeymoon on Maui. We stayed at the Ritz Carlton in Kapalua from June 17-25. From the moment we pulled up to the valet at the resort until the time the valet pulled up our car and it was time to leave we had the best time at this beautiful resort. The property is spreadout and gorgeous. Like many I'd read about the mildew smell in rooms. What mildew smell?!?!? The room, like the bathroom, was large, well appointed and very clean. We had outstanding service from the staff every single day. The treatment we received was outstanding from everyone. Everytime we saw someone on the staff they were saying "Aloha!" with a smile. The bellmen, the valets, and the concierge were knowledgable, helpful, and kind whenever we had questions or needed assistance. While the food at the restaurants, especially The Banyan Tree, was expensive, there were at least some low cost options nearby at the Honolua Store. Good tasting and cheap. We ate here for breakfast and lunch several times so we could spend the big money at the pricey places such as Spago's and Mama's Fish House. Like other reviews point out, you do walk alot to get to your room but its not that bad and it helps to walk off a big meal. The walk to the beach is five minutes and is a scenic stroll. Anyone who says its too far to walk probably has a hard time walking to their car in their driveway! The weather was great. It did rain occasionally in the morning and one time in the afternoon but the sun was out constantly. While it was breezy most of the time it made the strong sun bearable. All we can say is it truly was paradise and if we had our way we'd be there tomorrow! Mahalo to the Ritz Carlton staff. They really made our honeymoon truly memorable.

Reviews.Title: “Amazing Resort”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: My wife and i just returned from our honeymoon on Maui, and loved every second. The negative reviews for the Ritz are either employees of other hotels or are people who are never happy. The service was perfect, almost overwhelming. The beach was amazing and the distance was refreshing. If you plan on staying in Kaanapali, go to cancun and you will have a similar experience. The Ritz was pure perfection. In my opinion there is no where else to stay. Kapalua is paradise, and Kaanapali is too typical and overrun.

Reviews.Title: “Perfect, Negative Reviewers are Insane or Work for Other Hotels”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: This was our third trip to Maui, and our first stay at the Ritz in Kapalua. We were there during the first week of June, 2004. The Hotel itself and the grounds are immaculate. There is plenty of green space and gardens throughout. The pool is beyond relaxing and I belive it intentionally does not have waterslides and volleyball to facilitate a calm and tranquil day at the pool. Younger children may prefer a more waterpark like atmosphere so keep that in mind. I believe individuals on this site take isolated complaints and turn them into generalities. The pool service was excellent, so much so that you have to be careful when you can simply sign everything off to your room. As for the beach, yest in Kaanapali and Waimea the beach is literally a sun tan lotion bottle throw from the pool. For some that may be important. However, to classify the beach as being a "good distance" from the Ritz is misleading and speaks more towards someone's laziness. It is a two minute walk down a widing path that takes you past the sacred burial grounds they discovered when building the hotel. At the beach, there is another restaurant and bar. Moreover, for those who simply refuse to walk more than 10 feet on vacation there are stretch golf carts running almost continuously offering rides. The lobby was great in the evenings, and has hotel caliber musicians. I am not sure what some people expect, Sting performing at night while a dozen or so people sip 7 dollar beers and lava flows? The sushi bar is a tad expensive, but the excellent Sansei restaurant is located in Kapaula so make the 30 second drive down the road and enjoy the rolls there. On to location. Any one that thinks Kapalua is too far from everywhere, either visited from a town of 2000 people where nothing is further than the Walmart 2 minutes down County Line Road or should have ... oh I don't know looked at a map before visiting Maui. Yes, it is up from Kaanapali but in Island terms that means 5 minutes. Out of curiousity we timed each of our trips into Lahaina from the Hotel, average time was 12 minutes. If you can't spend 12 minutes in a car with the person you are vacationing with than maybe you have other issues to resolve prior to taking a vacation. The nice thing about being a little bit further away is the spaciousness of the resort. We went to Waimea and last time we stayed in Kaanapali and those places are excellent, maybe even preferable to many people. But the resorts are literally stacked right next to one another. Any green space surrounding a pool is covered in lawn chairs and lounges. The Ritz just felt like you had more space to yourself, there is hardly anyone ever next to you at the pool unless you wanted them to be (12 minute car complainers could swim and sun in isolation if they want). Plus, with the beach being down the path you don't get a bunch of on-lookers passing through because remember the beaches in front of the hotels are open to the public there is not some imaginary line. Obviously, weather is a concern depending on when you travel. If you are going during Maui's wet season (check a website this is easy to find) than maybe go a little South of Kapalua. If you are going in the summer there is little concern. Last point, I promise. The individual complaining about the age group at the Ritz. My wife and I are in our late 20's and thought there a wide age range of people at the resort. However, what did you expect when you chose to stay a Ritz Carlton, the same early 20 something crowd you encountered at the Best Western in Daytona during your senior year Spring Break. The Ritz is expensive, typically people of middle age tend to have the income to be able to stay at such a resort. All in all, take all the 1 star ratings of the Ritz with a grain of salt. I am not saying their complaints are not real, but they are certainly not reflective of what 90 percent of Ritz guests experience. There are those who are never satisfied and cannot wait to tell someone about it. Enjoy your trip

Reviews.Title: “Loved it!! Not one complaint!”
Reviews.Author: mauiedinmaui
Reviews.Content: Loved it! My husband and I flew to Maui to get married and stayed at the Ritz. It was beautiful! And the beds, my goodness, they are the most comfortable beds I've ever slept in. The staff was very friendly, the hotel was very clean. I read in one review that there was no beach. Not true. The private beach at the Ritz is actually pretty large and secluded. This is a very quiet hotel. No kids running around making loud noise. The scenery is georgeous. I would stay there again in a second! I highly reccomend it.

Reviews.Title: “The Typical Excellent Ritz Standard”
Reviews.Author: milhouse
Reviews.Content: This was my eighth trip to Hawaii. Having previously stayed at: Hapuna Prince (twice), Four Seasons Big Island, Four Seasons Wailea, Kauai Marriott, Hyatt Kauai, Kapalua Villas - so I do have some conception of what constitutes a nice Hawaiian resort (althought the Kauai Marriott, on my list, falls a long way from that). Additionally, I have also spent some time at most of the major hotels on the Big Island, Maui and Kauai (just checking them out). Regarding the complaints about the distance to the beach - it is at most a 500 yard walk to the beach. Plus, it is a very pleasant 500 yards. I can't for the life of me imagine the lazy slobs who find it so distressing that they would have to walk 500 leisurely yards to the beach. Big deal. As far as being a long ways away from civilization. First of all, there is also another hotel at the resort (in case you didn't realize that) - it's called the Kapalua Bay Hotel (and there are over 500 villas throughout the resort). There are also 3 golf courses, not one. Plus the best restaurant on the island is in Kapalua (Sansei). In any case, it's meant to be a retreat - if you wanted a ton of action then maybe you should have looked into Waikiki. Or if you want something in between a retreat and a ton of action (and you have a family) try Kaanapaali. Although, to my mind, if you don't have kids you will hate Kaanapaali because the pools and beaches are swarming with little kids. The food in Kaanapali (and Whaler's Village) is also pretty bad (it's meant for the Olive Garden and Spaghetti Factory clientele). The Ritz has top notch service and sits on a beautiful piece of land. The hotel is spectacular and I never encoutered any mildew smells. If I had to list my favorite Hawaiian Hotels, I would say that it would go something like this: 1) Four Seasons Big Island 2) Hapuna (very secluded, not meant for kids, with a breathtaking lobby). 3a) Ritz 3b) Hyatt 4) Mauna Lani 5) Kapalua Bay Hotel 6) Mauna Kea 7) Princeville 8) Grand Wailea 9) Four Seasons Wailea (nice, but the pool is just too damned crowded for a Four Seasons). Way down the list would be anything in Kaanapali or Waikoloa (too Disney-like) and then way down after that would be the Kauai Marriott (fails at even being Disney-like).

Reviews.Title: “Wonderful property”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: My husband and I celebrated our 25th anniversary at the Ritz in March, 2004. We loved our stay at the Ritz. Have stayed at other Ritz properties. Had read some of the reviews prior to our arrival and I was a little nervous. Once we arrived I can't imagine what other people have complained about. We were there on a Romance Package and from the moment we arrived we were given excellent service, our ocean front room was as close to the ocean as you can get. View, room and overall property is beautiful. It is quiet, elegant and has everything you need for a great trip.

Reviews.Title: “Pass on the Ritz”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: I am very surprised about the positive comments here. I wonder if some of the reviewers have stayed in Maui before to compare. We just returned from the Ritz Carlton and were not really all that impressed. The grounds are certainly nice but that is to be expected for a five star hotel and a five star price. Where to begin...The beach is very small and is quite a hike from the hotel itself, most people didn't make it past the pool. The level of service in the lobby bar is non-existent. It is almost like they wouldn't be paid if they tied to offer you another round. Someone mentioned the musicians were great, I would strongly diasgree, not only was the music bad, it was so loud you could not carry on a conversation without screaming to the person next to you. The location of the hotel is very far from anything, expect a long drive to anything you may plan on seeing. The fitness centre is plain embarassing. Some of the equipment looks like it was made in 1927, and the steam room in the Mens change area was not working half of the time we were there. When it was working it was not at all impressive, as a matter of fact the steam room at the YMCA here locally is more impressive. The door on the shower in our bathroom would not close, and we also had the mildew smell in our room. On a positive note, 1) the golf course does look very nice and I understand it is one of the best in the U.S. 2)If you like being isolated, this is the place for you, although most of Maui has the secluded feel to it as it is not as densely populated as other Islands. 3)There is a server whom my wife dubbed the "Juice Pusher" who was serving during the breakfast buffet that is highly entertaining. He ressembles the late Chris Farley, and won't leave you alone until you've had at least 3 glasses of OJ. As we were walking out we saw him entertaining another group by dancing around the table with the salt and pepper coconut shakers; I don't think I have ever had a more enjoyable breakfast. This is the 4th review I have written here and the first negative one. Ironically of the 4 places I have recently been to, this one was the most expensive, but the one most lacking in service. We were in Montego Bay at a 3 Star all inclusive resort a month ago and the service was incredible and for a lower price all meals and alcohol were included, plus the beach and pool areas were far superior. If you are considering a trip to Maui, I highly reccomend staying in the Kaanapali area, there is a variety of hotels and restaurants for the same price (or less) with better customer service, village shops and long beautiful beaches. As for me, this being my second trip to Maui, I am done. Based on the prices and service level offered in the Carribean with these all inclusive deals, I will going back there for my next hot vacation.

Reviews.Title: “The Relaxed Ritz Carlton”
Reviews.Author: TravelLovinMan
Reviews.Content: From the moment we neared the Ritz Carlton Kapalua, my fears about its remote location were relieved. Geographically, the area is gorgeous (reminds me somewhat of the Tuscany and Umbria regions of Italy) and the hotel had a very relaxed, very welcoming feel to it (which is nice after a long flight). Was a bit underwhelmed with the room we were given - mainly because of the condition of the carpet and the VERY crooked pictures on the walls (looked like the room had been hit by a tropical storm). Once we had the pictures in their correct position and had unpacked, we went down to enjoy an incredible meal in their premier restaurant (food, wine were excellent, live music in the restaurant was amazing, breezy tropical environment was perfect). Later, enjoyed a drink and more live music in the main hotel bar (I can't say enough good things about the musicians that performed at the hotel - a different group in both the restaurant and bar each night). Woke up early the first morning (4:30 AM or so) to the loud sounds of foot traffic on the floor above us (sounded like children running around). Was very concerned that the hotel had a noise problem, but they readily accomodated our request to change rooms and we never heard even a peep again for the remainder of the visit. Used the hotel gym twice, which was great (though some of the machines must be on loan from defunct fitness clubs - have never seen such worn pads in my life). Got a massage, sat in the sauna, etc. By day, we sat by the pool, which was very nice and well maintained. Went for long walks each morning, took naps, etc. Never wore a pair of long pants the entire stay - which was a pleasant surprise. Was glad we stayed at the Ritz Carlton and not one of the other top hotels we looked at in Wailea (there's new construction going on now in Wailea that makes a lot of noise. We had lunch there one day and found it disturbing. Couldn't wait to get back to our hotel). Overall had a truly relaxing experience at this property and was sad to have to leave our last day. Its casual atmosphere and welcoming feel was exactly what we were looking for in a vacation. Would consider making an annual trek here for relaxation.

Reviews.Title: “Great Stay”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: We had a fabulous stay at the Ritz in Kapalua. We only had one windy day out of seven days in Maui. The hotel has an intimate feel and a certain graciousness in the service. It's not "over the top" luxury, but a kind of understated luxury. Employees were courteous and very helpful. The pool area is well served with great towels, lovely drinks, and a good menu for snacking or lunching by the pool. Everyone seems to jog or golf in the morning, so people are up and going by 6 or 7 a.m. The morning coffee and Wall Street Journal are a nice way to start the day. Yes, the hotel is an hour from Wailea or the north shore, but everything as far as activities is spread out on Maui, so it didn't bother me. We snorkeled in Nipili and at Mile Marker 14 beaches which were fairly close and convenient. Guest Activities is very convenient. We booked our surfing lessons there. I'm not sure that it was worth the price, but it was fun to try to surf. Book an early morning lesson so that the wind won't be as much of a factor. It would have been nice for the hotel employees to tell us that.We did a spa day at the Grand Wailea. The concierge desk has the menu of services for us to review, and we booked the services ourselves. In comparing the two great hotels, it was clear that the Grand Wailea was "grand" and meant to take your breath away (as the prices there do also), and the Ritz-Carlton was meant to make you comfortable and pampered in your Maui vacation.Overall, I loved the hotel. It was a great experience. Karen

Reviews.Title: “Great Place and Definite 5 Star Service”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: I thought that this hotel was great. I agree with the previous review. I just got back from a honeymoon in Maui and everything at the Ritz was geared for relaxation, comfort, elegance, and super service. We enjoyed everything from the leis at the entrance to great room service at night. The Ritz had great service from everyone all the way from the conceirge (Cynthia was great) to the housekeeping staff. All we had to do was pick up the telephone and it was done for us. Froms shows and restaurants to snorkeling at Molokini. I am not sure which part of the resort the unhappy guests stayed at, but I thought it was great. The breakfast buffet is a must (try and include it in your room package), as it was the best that we ate all day (simple but great taste) - waffles, sausage, bacon, everything you would expect at a typical breakfast buffet. The on-site restaurant was not our style, only for the simple fact that it was Australian cuisine. The one and only drawback is that this resort is a little ways from everything, but you must keep in mind this is an island and nothing is far away. The tourist sites are all over the island so no hotel is really close to anything. On one final note, the Ritz was great and would suggest it for anyone anytime. Don't miss out on this great resort!

Reviews.Title: “LOVED it... and cant wait to go back!”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: The moment you arrive at the hotel your greeted with lei's for the entire family! Checkin was easy... however the hotel was booked so we were unable to get 2 rooms right next to each other (but it was of no problem to us). As youre walking towards the elevators you get wonderful views of the three tier pools and hot tub, plus the hotels restaurant. The people at the concierge desk are so polite... CYNTHIA was nice enough to squeeze us into restaurants and events that we had been told were full (she was SO WONDERFUL!). The breakfast buffet we had every morning was great. and each day there was always something new to choose from. Catching a good tanning spot by the pools were kinda difficult if u didnt arrive early enough but ince u found ur spot you were always offered beverages which was a plus, especially on hot days! Every place was easy to get to... and having a car was a PLUS. My family and i honestly had NO COMPLAINTS and we cant wait to go back again!

Reviews.Title: “Great People, but needs some work”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: I also was a little hesitant to book the Ritz Carlton, but my travel agent advised me not to take these ratings seriously. We spent 5 nights from March 20 - March 25 and, I've got to say most reviews on this site are accurate (except for the ones that say the place is a dump). The grounds are nice and well maintained. The staff was very friendly and courteous, the breakfast buffet (thank God it was included) was above average, but not worth what it would cost daily, and the beach grill, although very expensive, was really good. The staff around the pool area were very friendly and we loved the padded lounge chairs and chair covers and abundance of fresh towels. Unfortunately our weather stunk that week, but that of course wasn't the resort's fault. We went all over Maui the entire time and Kauai the week before, and the weather was it's same lousy self. We liked the location of the resort, b/c it was tucked away from all the busier places, but only a short 10minute drive to Kaanapali. The golf courses surrounding the resort were beautiful and very tempting, but I had to hold off this time. Definitely next time, if there is one. The lobby was very nice, the pool was nice (could use more frequent cleaning though), and our room was just OK. That was our only complaint. There was no doubt a damp smell coming from the A/C, which I think is gross, and the carpets were ugly and worn. The furniture needs to be updated, but the lanai was nice with new comfortable furniture, and the bathroom was very big and I liked the 2 shower idea. The lighting was bad in there, but that didn't bother us. The robes were awesome though, very thick and comfortable. The $15 resort fee is excessive, mainly b/c it didn't include valet parking. Otherwise, I wouldn't care that much, b/c hotels in disney have it, so I'm not surprised. All in all, we liked the resort, but unless they updated the rooms and took care of that odor coming from the Air Conditioning, I think I'd book a similarly priced hotel in Kaanapali or Wailea. It is nice, but should be nicer for a Ritz Carlton.

Reviews.Title: “cannot wait to go back”
Reviews.Author: vacationer24
Reviews.Content: I seriously had second thoughts about staying in this hotel based on what I read in Tripadvisor. I was worried about the rainy weather, service and damp smelling room. The Ritz Carlton, thankfully, ended up being a wonderful hotel and I should not have worried. The rooms were elegant and stately, even though I did smell dampness upon arrival, I totally forgot about it for the rest of our 10 day vacation. Every employee was courteous and was eager to help. The hotel grounds were beautiful and well cared for - and you do have to walk a ways to get to your room, but just consider it working off last night's dinner. We had wonderful weather and everyone was laying out at the beautiful pool. The beach is small and has good waves for bodysurfing. It was nice to be a little secluded from other hotels - rather than staying at "resort row" in Lahaina where the beach is huge and beautiful but everywhere you go there's a crowd. When we return to Maui we will definitely stay at the Ritz Carlton again- they helped make our vacation truly wonderful.

Reviews.Title: “Fantastic”
Reviews.Author: Jilliantraveler
Reviews.Content: Our recent stay at the Ritz was fantastic. The weather was not the best, but the resort was top notch. Kapalua resort area is beautiful. It reminded me of northern Minnesota with it's cabins and pine trees. The resort sits high on the hill. A Hawaiian burial site was discovered when they first started construction on the Ritz, so the hotel was moved back. There is a shuttle that will take you down to the beach and back up the hill, or its an easy walk. The beachside restaurant is great. Tiki tourches and amazing views. They will soon be open for dinner as well as lunch. The Honolua General Store is within walking distance and you can easily find a very inexpensive tasty breakfast or lunch. Take some time to get to know the history of the area, it's quite fasinating. Service at the Ritz was top notch. Everyone was happy and was there to make your vacation great. They have nightly entertainment in the lobby/bar area and it's wonderful. The pool area is large, and service at the pool is quick. They Banyon Tree restaurant which is poolside is quite cozy and has wonderfully prepared dinners. Out room was nice and large, and the bed was very cozy. Maid service was consistant but not overly intruding. I hate when they come in and line up my personal things. The housekeeping here knew what to touch, and what to leave alone. Nothing was too much ... if you needed something just ask. We received a complimentary upgrade to ocean front with a smile upon request. Free coffee in the morning was a bonus. We even asked for a quick run by the pastry table at the buffet one morning and they simply waved us through... again with a smile. The drive into Lahaina or Kanapali was quick and easy. I highly recommend this resort to anyone visiting Maui.

Reviews.Title: “Maui Ritz-Carlton worth every penny”
Reviews.Author: Isky
Reviews.Content: This resort was incredible...The golf course and hotel was the best I saw on the island of Maui. We visited other hotels, like to Marriott for their luau and liked it, but nothing we saw could top the Ritz. Staff was wonderful. Pool is beautiful. Food very pricey though. Golf academy is highly recommended - my husband loved the one on one attention from the PGA pro/teacher. Hotel turn down service was twice a day. Beware of the additional $15 a day resort fee - take advantage of this by getting the free kona coffee and newspapers daily and using the free self-parking. This hotel is an hour from the airport...you will need a car even though the hotel offers a shuttle to only nearby shops and restaurants. Also, the spa was incredible - expensive, but well worth it.

Reviews.Title: “Ritz-Carlton, Kapulua an A++++ Resort”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: I have vacationed 5 times to Maui and stayed at the Ritz-Carlton on Maui 4 times. This is by far the best Hotel on the entire island. Please ignore the other postings calling this Resort a Holiday Inn, sorry but they must be ignorant. My last vist was in July 2004, we stayed at the Ritz for 5 days then went to the Westin in Ka'anappali for 4 days for a deal to listen to a time share presentation. First, the Ka'anappali area is like Miami beach, very, very crowded, small beaches and to congested for me. Staying at the Westin was even worse, the rooms are small, dirty and never renovated and the pools were over crowed and that area reminded me of Disney World, very streeful, did not remind me of Maui. When we stayed at the Westin, we went back to the Ritz to swim in there clean, quiet pool. When I checked in at the Ritz, we were unknowing upgraded to a Suite, which was awesome. Please check out *************8. Kapalua and Honolua Bay are ranked in the best snorkeling in the WORLD. I have 2 small kids and bought a water ski belt so they were able to snorkel. Kapalua and Honolua Bay are a 5 minute free shuttle away. The Ritz-Carlton does not reside next to any resort, it sits on I am guessing at least a couple hundred acres, no other hotel in site. It does get windy in the morning but clears up. If you want to bake in the sun at 6:00am with no wind then stay at the 4 Seasons. If you want to stay at a crowed area then stay some where in Ka'anappli. The Ritz has 4 golf courses surrounding the Resort, the PGA starts off with the Mercedes in January on one of the courses. If you go you must stop at the Honolua Store, it is abouta 5 minute walk or a 1 minute drive, it is a local food store, that serves lunch and sells fresh pineaple. I have stayed at Ritz 4 times and I am currently planning trip no.5, back to Ritz for 2005. If I win the lottery, I will retire at the Ritz. Also I get the package stay 4 night and get the 5 night free and that includes 2 free brekfast buffets everyday. If you want desert like heat stay at the 4 Seasons, if you want crowds and congestion stay somewhere in Ka'anappali, if you want to relax and enjoy peace and quiet stay at the RITX-CARLTON Kapalua, Maui.

Reviews.Title: “The worst Ritz-Carlton”
Reviews.Author: Ryan.W
Reviews.Content: Compared to the five other Ritz-Carltons I've stayed at this was by far the worst. (Naples is the best!) Perhaps it is the size, with nearly 600 rooms it is the largest property, and most likely this is why the service is pitiful. This hotel is the equivalent of a Holiday Inn. I waited over an hour at the small local airport just 10 miles away because no one told me to take the Kapalua shuttle; I was waiting for the Ritz-Carlton shuttle. None exists! At arrival, I loaded my own luggage on to the cart, and when the bellmen finally decided to help he showed me to my room and literally never uttered a word. The carpet had a huge stain, the bedspreads were tattered and one of the lamps never worked. I was never given a key to the mini-bar and when requested one it showed up two days later. The bartenders were surly. At the beachside bar which is at a great distance from the hotel there were only four stools at the entire bar and when my food arrived and it was raining I had to stand and eat, when I complained the bartender actually asked another guest to stand while I used his barstool (TRUE STORY!). It was embarassing and very uncharacteristic of the whole "ladies and gentleman" philiosophy. In the terrace room for the overpriced breakfast ($38.00 for one a la carte) I cut my lip on the broken juice glass and never even received an apology or perhaps a credit to return to the restaurant. When all of this was reported to the front desk, the clerk advised he did not care as he was leaving in the morning to work at the Lake Las Vegas property. And don't bother addressing your concerns to the GM. He is newly in from the Fairmont Whistler B.C. and could care less. Perhaps he is just overwhelmed. Combined with the poor location, constant wind and clouds and the cool June temps, I wouldn't stay here again if you paid me. Go to the Four Seasons and relish in true service and hospitality.

Reviews.Title: “Dog of a hotel”
Reviews.Author: BillVol
Reviews.Content: From the minute we pulled onto the property, it was terrible. It took forever and a day for valet to greet us. We had to ask for our lei. Our room was ten miles from check-in. Room was not clean. Beach is ten miles from hotel. Weather is terrible on this part of the island -- rainy and windy. No poolside service to speak of -- especially when compared to Four Seasons. The breakfast buffet had flies crawling all over the food. I thought I was on Candid Camera. But no, this was actually happening! We checked out and headed for the Four Seasons the next night. Absolutely no comparing these two properties. The Four Seasons is far superior to the Ritz Kapalua. But then many Fairfield Inns I've been in are superior to the Ritz Kapalua. I just wish I could give it less than one star.

Reviews.Title: “Honeymoon heaven”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: We came to Maui for our honeymoon and the Ritz was incredible. This is the best hotel on the island by far. A full star above the Four Seasons. The hotel is on a 20 acre cliff overlooking the ocean. The lobby is on the sixth floor and looks down on the three magnificent pools. The service is superior. Even when the hotel was full it never felt crowded. The hotel has a beach house with food and drinks adjacent to a nearly private beach. The rooms were very comfortable and had large bathrooms and great bedding. The only minor problem with this property is the weather. Everything you hear is true. If there is rain within 50 miles of Maui, it will rain at the Ritz. You can expect at least 2 one minute rain mists spread among the clouds, and at least one 20-30 minute shower per day. If you drive 10 minutes south, these rain clouds are mysteriously gone. Don't let that stop you, however, because this hotel was rated by one of the travel mags as the best Ritz-Carlton in the world back in 1999, and it is by far the best hotel we have ever stayed in.

Reviews.Title: “The second time's the charm!!”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: I should start off by saying that my husband and I stayed at this hotel 5 years ago and were not impressed. When I told the hotel of our problems they invited us back for three nights. We actually stayed for eight nights and this time was completely different. We really enjoyed this hotel. The staff was very friendly, accomodating and definitely demonstrated the feeling of "aloha". As far as rooms go it is a long walk-especially if you have a deluxe ocean view or ocean front, my husband thought he smelled mildew occasionally (I never did)from the air conditioning. The room itself was fine. They have pickled bamboo furniture in an effort to look tropical, but it does look a bit dated. The bathrooms were very nice-we even had two showers in our bathroom. The hotel is set away from the beach (due to an ancient Hawaiian burial grounds)so the views are definitely not up close ocean views. I had a deluxe ocean view which overlooked the golf course, nearby condos, a church and then the ocean and Molokai. It was a beautiful view, but if you're not aware how far back you are it could be disappointing. As for the breakfast buffet, it's great if it's part of your package, but at $25 per personyou may be disappointed. There was definitely more food at the buffet five years ago. The weather was off/on windy and rainy the whold time we stayed, that's just how this side of the island is. The only negatives are the $15 a day resort fee (crazy just add it in to the cost of the rooms)and how far away the guest parking spots are-all the up close spots are for valet. In a previous review someone mentioned not being able to use their computer at the resort. They now have a high speed wireless setup available (however my husband who sets up networks for a living could not get this to work and we heard others say the same thing). They do have a wireless set up in the business center that you can sign up for for $10 a day. You do have to be with 200 feet of the business center to use it, but they have several table in the hallway to use. We found that it worked out to check our email and get coffee in the morning. This hotel is definitley special. There is so much space and it feels very relaxed and private. I really enjoyed my stay here.

Reviews.Title: “we loved it!”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: We stayed here in Nov 2003 and had a grat experience! We had a club room, which was great - access to private concierge and food, beer, wine, sodas all day long. Our room was wonderful - no mildew as some seem to have experienced. All staff members we encountered were helpful and friendly. The only draw back we found was not actually the fault of the hotel, but rather the location. It was rainy and extremely windy. We have friends who have stayed there twice, and had the same weather conditions as us both times. Hard to have the sunny beach vacation you think of in Hawaii with weather like that. We found it very restful.

Reviews.Title: “Kapalua Ritz a serene gem tucked in the West Maui Mts”
Reviews.Author: AKHHagerstown_MD
Reviews.Content: Our stay at the Ritz Carlton Kapalua (Feb. 1-6) was our third trip to Maui in the last 18 months as our son recently moved to the island. We were anxious to stay at this property which is located 20 minutes north of Lahaina, but an hour's drive to the Kihei/Wailea area where our son resides. The Kapalua area is extremely beautiful and quite different from other areas of the island. The property is spacious and beautifully landscaped with gorgeous pines and flowering trees. Rooms are pleasant and well-appointed. It has a very serene feel and understated elegance. It is however located on the windward side of the island prone to frequent clouds and showers. The property does not offer a sunrise or sunset (which we love in Maui) beacause of its position on the hillside. The beach is only a short walk down the hill, but is not nearly as nice as beaches in Kaanapali and Kihei/Wailea. The pool is very nice...but the unfortunate weather prevented us from spending the time there that we would have liked. It is necessary to have a car at this property as it is somewhat remote, but in fairness doing anything in Maui requires a car!) The concierge can make arrangements for any sort of activity desired where transportation is included. This property is perfect for golfers,(although we are not golfers, the course is supposedly terrific--Mercedes Championship just held here!) those seeking quiet rest and relaxation and those interested in the beauty of this area(two great snorkeling bays located nearby). It offers an incredible spa, a decent gym and an outrageously delicious buffet breakfast, although equivilantly expensive. The Banyon Tree for dinner was fine dining at its best...elegant, delicious and alas...expensive. Kapalua is a nice spot on the island, but it might not be the best choice for those seeking sunny beaches, ocean sunsets, and accessibiltity to a more vibrant setting.

Reviews.Title: “Needs some serious work!”
Reviews.Author: sullyboy
Reviews.Content: Just got back from a 4 night stay (14-18 JAN 2004). The location was fine (about 20 minutes north of Lahaina), other than the fact that you have more wind in Kapalua than say Wailea or Ka'anapali. The wind only became an issue after taking a dip in the pool and then trying to lay out in the sun. Quite chilly and unpleasant. We had no rain during our stay.As for the rooms, they could use MAJOR work. We made the front desk move us to a new room, because our first room smelled damp, and strongly of mold/mildew. I had previously read that some people encountered the same problem on tripadvisor.com, but didn't figure we'd have the same problem. I've been to many hotels on all of the Hawaiian Islands, and have never encountered this problem. So to say that "it just happens" in Hawaii is absurd. In reality, it "just happens" to those hotels (like the Ritz Kapalua) who don't bother to keep up their facilities.Our new room still smelled a bit musty, but due to the long walk back to the front desk, we decided that we'd just make do. Anyway, we are not the type of travelers that spend much time in our room. Our first room was what they called "ocean view'. Because the hotel is not directly on the water, "ocean view" means you get a small sliver of ocean from your balcony.Our new room had virtually no view whatsoever, but as I said, it was quite a trek to keep walking between the front desk and the room, so we decided to accept the new room.A word about both rooms... Having seen two separate rooms which both exhibited the same sign of deterioration, I can say with some level of accuracy that this hotel is very sub-par when it comes to other Ritz-Carltons.Both rooms had very ratty looking furniture. One of the rooms had a giant stain all over the carpet, and the other room's carpet was worn and filthy. We did not walk around barefoot in the room. Tip: call housekeeping and ask for slippers... at least you can have something comfortable to wear between the bed and the bathroom. The screen on the screen door was totally ripped in our second room. Good thing we didn't encounter any mosquitoes around the resort.Both rooms had very old televisions... you know, the 14" Sony's from 1985? That is what they reminded me of anyway. Again, we don't watch TV when we go to Hawaii since we?d rather spend our time outdoors, but it?s just one more item not up to par with the Ritz standards.The bathrooms were dated... very old marble showing signs of wear.We only did breakfast at the hotel, and only once, because of the LOUSY service and overpriced $25 buffet. Let me tell you, I've had better breakfast buffets for $10 at Hyatt Hotels.Poolside service was very indifferent. Only one lady employee treated us with a smile every time. The heavy set blonde attendant needs to get an attitude check, or check into a new line of work. Her service was consistently rude and indifferent.The $15 daily resort fee is the straw that breaks the camel's back. For a daily $15 charge (which you may not decline), you receive 'complimentary' coffee/tea in the morning, in the lobby. But don't sleep in until 10am like we did...or you will miss the coffee and tea service. Silly us, we thought we were on vacation... but apparently you must set an alarm for 9am in order to get your $15 money's worth for the day.That is the only material good you receive for the $15 daily fee. They name a bunch of intangible services such as "the privilege of shopping in the lobby shops and charging your purchases to your room". You be the judge of that, but I don't think it costs them $15/day to negotiate with those merchants, to let the guests sign charges to their rooms.So for us, we paid a total of $60 for resort fees for our 4 days, and we got a total of 6 cups of coffee. You do the math...for $10 per cup of coffee; I'd just assume buy two large bags of premium-grade Peaberry Kona Coffee to take home.We will absolutely not return to the Ritz-Carlton Kapalua. Their combination of lousy rooms, rude employees and irritating resort fee is good reason to keep us away in the future.I almost forgot... beware of lunatic bellhops in the narrow hallways. (By the time you get all the housekeeping carts in the halls, you literally must walk in a single file line to pass them.) We were "forced off the road" so to speak twice by the same bellhop guy, who insisted on not yielding to us, the guests. Again, silly me for thinking the guest would be given the right of way, especially at a supposed 5-star hotel.The only nice employees we encountered were: the tall brunette pool-attendant, the housekeeping women, and the short Hawaiian girl who greets you with a lei. Also the Caucasian gall at the concierge desk.If you don?t want to pay ridiculous parking fees, there is a self parking area, albeit a short walk from the lobby.Do yourself a favor and avoid this hotel. We will return to Mau?i, but we?ll stay at the Four Seasons in Wailea. We checked out the Four Seasons Wailea during our trip, and it is just miles above and beyond the Ritz.I will continue to patronize other Ritz Carlton?s, because I know the Ritz in Kapalua is just an exception to the brand. I would like to know how such an awful hotel maintains the Ritz logo.Overall, the staff seems very full of themselves. We got the overall impression that the staff forgot that their job is to serve us. We?re paying them to serve us, but they behaved like they were on a vacation too.This hotel was nothing more than a 3-star Marriott or Hilton in terms of rooms and service.

Reviews.Title: “Great vacation!”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: I just returned from a great vacation. I'm astounded as I read some of the other reviews. This was truly a wonderful hotel. True, you do have to hoof it down to the beach. But the Ritz made a decision to NOT disturb a sacred Hawiian burial site. That is total class in my book. I did have to pay a lot of money for the buffet, but on the Big Island I paid the same at the Marriott. Yep the pine trees got to me, I could not figure that one until I read the history of the plantation. Still, Palm trees would have seem more Hawaiian. If you are looking for crowds and a very close beach go to the Hyatt. In fact when I go back I may stay at the Marriott because I do have two small children. But, this hotel was truly classy, my wife said it was a total relaxation compared to the madness in Lahania. Definitely earned all 5 stars despite what other might say.

Reviews.Title: “Honeymoon Paradise!!!”
Reviews.Author: jshaw14
Reviews.Content: My wife and I stayed at the Ritz for our honeymoon from Dec 19-26. We loved every aspect of it! The accomodations were more than overwhelming. The staff was very polite and helpful. The food and drinks were excellent too! You can sit in the lobby at night with the trade winds relaxing breathe as entertainment sings/dances for you. The golfing is one that you will never experience anywhere else! The only negatives, which are none to worry about are, the fact that you need to walk about 1/4 to get to your room if it is an ocean view, or about 1/2 mile to walk to the Ritz's private ocean beach. Other reviews complained about the prices, but if you stay in Hawaii, and at the Ritz Carlton, you should expect the higher proce, this is no econolodge! The only other factor is if you have allergies. If you are allergic to mildew, than take your allergy medicine with you, other than that, we will be back again!!

Reviews.Title: “Poor Location, Prices Astounding”
Reviews.Author: bradowpc
Reviews.Content: The exorbitant cost of extras was astounding, even by Ritz standards. First of all there is a daily "resort fee" which is not disclosed until check-in. We decided to eat all meals off-campus after our first morning, when a totally ordinary buffet breakfast for two totaled more than $50. A restaurant recommendation made by the concierge was clearly a kickback arrangement with nauseatingly disgusting food and equally obnoxious prices. After paying roughly $17 for two beers later in the week, I had reached my tolerance threshold. Added to the hotel's poor location in the heart of the "condoville" ticky-tacky region of North Maui and its lack of easy beach access, the experience failed to meet expectations.

Reviews.Title: “RITZ WAS WELL WORTH IT”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: My husband and I just got back from a 5 night stay at the Ritz Kapalua (12/14-12/18) and we enjoyed ourselves throughly. I too was concerned about some feedback I had read, but I really don't understand where the negative vibes are coming from. First off, the weather. Yes, it is a bit windy and overcast in Kapalua, but we managed to get a tan after only a few hours of laying out. Once it rained at night (i.e. 3 AM) and there was one only one instance of a rainy mist at 10 AM that cleared in less than ten minutes! Constant tradewinds keep you from feeling like you're frying in the sun. DT Fleming Beach is a five minute walk at best and the path is paved. Kapalua Beach is also nice (our friends were married there) but it's a shuttle or short car ride away. The rooms were not out of date or musty smelling. (Musty and out of date is where we stayed in Oahu & that smell was from the humidity! ) We slept with the lanai door open, never felt the need for AC. Bathrooms are marble with shower, shower/tub & two sinks. I remember at least two washcloths because I used them everyday & at night they give you new towels when housekeeping comes by for a second time. Food prices were consistent with what you'd find in almost any hotel on Maui or Hawaii (i.e. $12 for an omlette). Best deal going at Kapalua is a two minute walk to the Honolua store for fresh pineapple or take out breakfast or lunch for under $5.00. Service friendly, especially the girls working the Concierge Desk. My husband loved the golfing too!

Reviews.Title: “Modified Expectations”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: Stayed December 5-9, 2004. Location: Feels like you've arrived in the pacific northwest. Property is surrounded by pineapple plantations and the golf course. There are many tall evergreen trees, which is nice, but makes you feel like you're not in Maui. Weather: Be prepared for cool, windy and possibly wet weather as compared to other areas on the island (Wailea, for instance). We ended up leaving the resort early most every day in search of better weather. Rooms: The room was somewhat adequate, but the furnishings need serious updating as well as the overall decor (paint, peeling wallpaper, etc.). Ritz needs to put money in remodeling the rooms of the hotel. The overall feel of the room was not 5-star. Public Spaces/Lobby: Lobby was nice for drinking complimentary coffee in the morning, but you're likely to be surrounded by conference attendees who are discussing business at tables nearby. The hallways need to be redone with new wallpaper and paint for a more simple, but elegant look. The current wallpaper is too busy and tacky. Spa/Gym: Luxurious and inviting. The gym was small, but well laid out. The steam room and sauna in the spa were wonderful. Grounds: Beautiful grounds, very manicured. Pool was very nice as well. It would be nice if the pool had umbrellas for shade. DT Fleming Beach: Rough beach - quite a ways downhill from the resort. Not for kids. The Kapalua Bay beach in front of Kapalua Bay hotel is probably better (we didn't go). Service/Staff: Service was very competent and efficient. The concierge was helpful. The complimentary shuttle was a nice amenity. We didn't use the staff much as we are very much self sufficient. Overall: The property has become a predominantly conference hotel. Unless you can get a very good rate here, which we got using the Hawaii website, you are better off spending your money at Four Seasons or Grand Wailea if you are looking for a 5-star experience. It's rated as a 5-star, but felt like a Hilton. Next time, we plan on either renting a house on the Northshore or staying at a condo in Wailea. Tip: Take the shuttle to the Bay Club and/or the Kapalua Bay Hotel for happy hour. The Bay Club has $4 drinks from approx. 5:30-6 p.m. with a three-piece jazz band on weekends. There's also a happy hour available at the Lehua Lounge from approx. 5-6:30 p.m. Also 50% off sushi prices at Sansei after 10 p.m.

Reviews.Title: “Horribley run hotel... a total rip off”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: Besides the physical problems facing this hotel (it's located 10 minutes from the beach) the rooms are dirty (I had them move me three times - and each time the hotel put me in a room where the bed spread looked like it had been used to film a porno movie), the service is indifferent at best (they seem to think if they say "Aloha" or "Maholo" enough that will cover for bad service. The towels were ratty... when my wife requested an extra washcloth (to save money the hotel only puts one washcloth in a room) they asked her why she needed it! Add this to the food being overpriced and mediocre, the valet lost my car for half an hour, the fact they charge you $15 extra a day for a "resort fee" (doesn't the swimming pool come as part of the hotel?) the in room internet only works if you have a computer running Windows 98 or below(not above !!!), the business center closes at 6 PM (yet you can shop and buy overpriced garbage until midnight at the hotel's stores), this is a hotel worth avoiding at all cost. They should fire the staff, price things honestly (get rid of the resort fee), clean the rooms and maybe they will be as good as the Best Western.

HotelInfo.Name: Ritz-Carlton, Kapalua
HotelInfo.Address: 1 Ritz-Carlton Drive, Kapalua, Maui, HI 96761
